alert.note: Alert for Appanoose; Davis; Jasper; Lucas; Mahaska; Marion; Marshall; Monroe; Polk; Poweshiek; Story; Tama; Wapello; Warren; Wayne (Iowa) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Winter Storm Warning issued January 01 at 3:07AM CST until January 02 at 12:00AM CST by NWS DesMoines
info.description: ...Significant Storm With Dangerous Cold to Impact Today and Tonight... .A significant storm system with moderate to heavy snow over portions of central and southern Iowa will impact the area today. The combination of strong north winds and a dry, powdery snow will cause blowing and drifting snow and potentially significant travel problems in the areas affected. Also, bitter cold temperatures and dangerous wind chills will occur through most of the event with sub-zero wind chills expected through tonight when the coldest air of the season moves into Iowa. Dangerous wind chill values will extend into Sunday morning over most of the region. ...WINTER STORM WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 6 AM THIS MORNING TO MIDNIGHT CST TONIGHT... ...WIND CHILL ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM MIDNIGHT TONIGHT TO NOON CST SUNDAY... * WHAT...For the Winter Storm Warning, heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 3 to 8 inches with locally higher amounts possible nearer the Iowa Missouri border. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph. For the Wind Chill Advisory, very cold wind chills expected. Wind chills as low as 30 below zero. * WHERE...Central and Southern Iowa. * WHEN...For the Winter Storm Warning, from 6 AM this morning to midnight CST tonight. For the Wind Chill Advisory, from midnight tonight to noon CST Sunday. * IMPACTS...The dangerously cold wind chills could cause frostbite on exposed skin in as little as 10 minutes.
info.instruction: If you must travel, keep an extra flashlight, food, and water in your vehicle in case of an emergency. Use caution while traveling outside. Wear appropriate clothing, a hat, and gloves. The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can be obtained by calling 5 1 1.
